The EU Commission unexpectedly raised new concerns about the viability of the LCH.Clearnet SA remedy in relation to access to bond and repo trading feeds currently provided by MTS. MTS is a trading platform for European Government bonds and other fixed income securities with a focus on Italian underlyings. LSEG is majority shareholder and owns a 60% stake; the remaining part is owned by consortium of 26 shareholders. We estimate the revenue share of MTS to LSEG at c.7% with a significantly lower contribution to profitability. The Commission seems to be concerned that the disposal of LCH.Clearnet SA could be compromised if the trading flow from fixed income that is usually sent to the clearing house were diverted to an asset within Deutsche Börse/LSEG group i.e. Eurex or LCH.Clearnet Ltd.

RSA reported strong full year results last Thursday. Operating profit was a 6% beat to consensus, on the back of a 1% top-line beat, 0.4% point combined ratio beat at 94.2% and a 6% investment income beat. DPS was a similar beat at 16p, with the Final up 52%, albeit the full year at 41% of operating profit was towards the lower end of the 40-50% target range. Tangible NAV, which was impacted by the recently announced UK Legacy sale, increased by only 1p in the year to 281p, slightly below our 286p forecast, with net profit of only £18m versus our £38m forecast, after another year of numerous charges (principally restructuring, debt buyback and Legacy sale). The Solvency II ratio was also slightly light versus our forecast (no consensus) of 162%, with a bigger negative from credit spread narrowing than expected, albeit still at the top of 130-160% target range.

PM11:00am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:29am

We raise 2017E and 2018E operating EPS by 2%, with 2017E bottom-line EPS cut by 21% on higher restructuring charges and the cost of exiting the Legacy Adverse Development Cover. Broadly, raised top-line, underwriting profits and lower taxes have outweighed the impact of lower investment income (for 2018) and a more conservative reconciliation of earned premium. We have left our assumption of debt reduction unchanged from our February 9th note ‘Legacy deal leads to EPS upgrade’, when we put through a 6% increase to 2018E EPS. We have raised DPS by one pence in each year for a 48% pay-out in 2018 – that, and the lower starting tangible NAV, mean that tangible NAV falls by 5% and 3% in 17E and 18E (the unwind of unrealised gains remains a material headwind to NAV growth).

11:29 am

With these results another data-point of improving underlying performance, we continue to see our target forward PE multiple of 12.5x, broadly in-line with other UK non-life insurers and a premium to European composite peers, as appropriate, albeit success in achieving and sustaining updated targets should justify a higher multiple over time.
Our raised target price of 655p (from 640p) equates to 2.3x 17E tangible equity (from 2.2x) for a ROE for 18E raised from 17.5% to 18.8%, for a 3.2% dividend yield in 2017E, with prospects for additional capital return in 2018. This gives a 12 month total return in the low double digits, and we raise our recommendation from Hold to BUY. Next newsflow is Q1 trading on May 4th

BE11:40am

The lack of any mention of Jorge Paulo Lemann, or his 3G associates, in the annual letter issued by Berkshire this past Saturday, is a stark contrast to the glowing (well-articulated) praise showered on 3G in last year’s letter, and the one issued in Feb 2015, both of which clearly left the door open to future “friendly” deals. Obviously, we can only speculate about what this may all mean, if anything. Perhaps, 3G wants to keep a lower profile, so they requested no mentions? Perhaps, it is all too sensitive right now, given the friction with Unilever (to use a diplomatic term), so better for Berkshire not to write anything regarding 3G? Or perhaps, the lack of mention is a sign of a starting schism (a crack) and looming reluctance to do more deals, on the part of Berkshire? We can only speculate, but if the latter were true, then it would have significant implications for the share price of KHC and would also make us (and the market) have to reconsider the potential list of M&A targets for KHC (i.e., smaller fodder?). With earnings growth already apparently slowing at KHC (offsets to synergies), and a potentially more limited M&A pool (hypothetically speaking), then KHC multiples could compress (it trades at 2017 PE 26x and EBITDA 16.5x). Still, Berkshire does own 325.6Mn shares in KHC at present (worth $30.3Bn at Friday’s close), and was part of the Unilever bid (ULVR will finish an internal review in early April; the Sunday Telegraph claims a large stakeholder is calling for ULVR to sell the entire Food business), so for the time being it may be too early to predict some form of schism. But investors should factor this as part of their scenario analysis. On a separate point, and maybe stating the obvious, we think KHC is in a bind: can they just move on from ULVR and go look elsewhere? We do not think so. After Paul Polman’s stand, Irene, Indra, Ken, would probably not fold as quickly as Bill Johnson and John Cahill, especially now knowing that Warren Buffett will enforce his rule: only friendly deals.

On September 18, 2014 the Scottish electorate voted in a referendum on the question ""Should Scotland be an independent country?" In the end 2,001,926 people voted for Scotland to remain in the Union with England and Wales while 1,617,989 were in favour of independence (1). In the aftermath of the vote then Prime Minister David Cameron said "The debate has been settled for a generation ... there can be no disputes, no re-runs, we have heard the settled will of the Scottish people." (2). He may have spoken prematurely.

PM11:46am

Speaking on June 24 of last year, Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said that a second referendum on Scottish independence was "highly likely" and that the Scottish Government would begin preparing legislation (3). This issue resurfaced again following an interview given by the First Minister to BBC Radio Scotland in early January in which she indicated she was prepared to "put aside" the issue of independence "in terms of the timetable of Brexit" if the UK were able to remain in the single market (4). It was therefore not particularly surprising that Prime Minister Theresa May's speech on Brexit in January (5) elicited a swift response from the First Minister. She stated: "The UK government cannot be allowed to take us out of the EU and the single market...without Scotland having the ability to choose between that and a different future. With her comments today, the Prime Minister has only succeeded in making that choice more likely" (6). She subsequently told the BBC (when asked if a second vote was "all but inevitable"): "I think that is very likely the case" (7).

11:46 am
PM11:46am

When Ms Sturgeon was told on the BBC's Andrew Marr show at the start of the year that the view in London was she was bluffing and that she would not win another referendum, she replied: "They will be making a big mistake if they think that I am in any way bluffing" (8). Evidence that this might be the case emerged on Thursday lunchtime when Reuters quoted Charles Grant, an advisor to the Scottish government's Standing Council on Europe, as saying that "I believe the Scottish government is thinking very, very seriously about going for an independence referendum next year." (9) He added: "They feel they have enough emotion and momentum to overcome the economic downsides... the harder the Brexit, the more likely they are to break away" (a BMG poll published in The Herald on February 8 showed 49% of those surveyed supported independence with 51% opposing it, after "don't know" votes were removed (10)).

PM11:46am

Evidence of the potential importance of the story for the FX markets emerged this morning with EUR/GBP rallying around ¾% on the back of a story in The Times that the UK government is preparing for Nicola Sturgeon to call a second independence referendum to coincide with the triggering of Article 50 next month. The paper noted that "the prime minister could reject the demand, but such a move would risk causing a constitutional crisis. Membership of the European Union is a pre-requisite to be considered for membership of the EUR (13). However, speaking to the BBC on February 16 2014, the then president of the European Commission Jose Manuel Barroso noted: " I don't want to interfere on your referendum here, your democratic discussion here, but of course it will be extremely difficult to get the approval of all the other member states to have a new member coming from one member state. We have seen Spain has been opposing even the recognition of Kosovo, for instance. It is therefore seems unlikely given Mr. Barroso's comments that Scotland could become part of the European Union and then a part of the Euro-area straight away.

It is, nevertheless, possible that Scotland could use the EUR without being part of the Euro-area. Still, this raises exactly the same issues as using GBP when it comes to the matter of setting monetary policy or having a lender of last resort. In other words Scotland needs its own currency first and the appropriate monetary authorities if it was to join the EUR.
